I believe that it is highly likely that between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020 an armed group in Yemen will engage in a campaign systematically killing 1,000 or more civilians in Yemen. Early Warning Project’s own risk assessment rates the risk in Yemen for mass killings as high, currently 6th in the world because Yemen is currently experiencing mass killings. It is unlikely that these mass killings will halt in upcoming months. Human Rights Watch issued a report in November of 2018 regarding the deteriorating situation in Yemen in which 6,782 civilians had been killed and 10,768 wounded largely as a result of coalition air strikes that indiscriminately target civilians and combatants alike. In addition, the illegitimate Houthi government has “disappeared” many civilian journalists, lawyers, and activists. Perhaps the largest threat is the blocking of humanitarian aid by numerous armed groups which has placed 14 million people at risk of starvation and a cholera epidemic. International Crisis Group has alerted that the situation in Yemen as of May 2019 has deteriorated and is at a higher risk of continued violent conflict. Military escalation between Iran and Saudi Arabia increases the risk for further Saudi-led coalition air strikes against Iran backed Houthi forces on the ground in Yemen. In a 7 June 2019 report on the Complex Emergency in Yemen released by USAID states that as recently as 24 May an air strike conducted hit a fuel station killing 12 civilians. USAID also recorded approximately 364,000 cases of Cholera across Yemen, which if medical humanitarian aid continues to be restricted by armed groups may result in many more deaths than the 640 deaths reported. UNDP released a report 30 April 2019 claiming that if a ceasefire is not implemented by the end of the year the conflict could result in a death toll of 233,000 people approximately 102,000 of which would be conflict related deaths and 131,000 would be from starvation and lack of proper health services resulting from the current difficulties in providing access to humanitarian aid. Mines and IEDs are also increasingly impacting civilians, ACLED reported in January 2019 that there has been at least 267 civilian fatalities related to IEDs and mines planted by Houthis. These mines and IEDs present a larger concern for civilians living outside of metropolitan areas.

If someone is asking, there is a probability that this will happen because there's a reason for the question to be asked. Civilian casualties have increased significantly since the ceasefire, which is an indicator of likelihood of violent campaign. The veto of the resolution to remove the United States from the conflict means a continuance of support for the Saudi-led coalition and potentially contributes to the likelihood of ongoing conflict, increasing civilian risk. High casualty numbers in the past indicate likelihood of continuing casualties. That said, the greatest threat probably lies in disease/famine, or action from the Saudi coalition, none of which count as armed groups from Yemen.  https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/16/us/politics/trump-veto-yemen.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FYemen&action=click&contentCollection=world&region=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=3&pgtype=collection https://www.nrc.no/news/2019/march/Civilian-casualties-double-in-parts-of-Yemen-since-ceasefire/ https://www.cfr.org/blog/top-conflicts-watch-2019-yemen https://www.securitycouncilreport.org/monthly-forecast/2019-01/yemen-2.php https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/civilian-casualties-in-yemen-average-123-per-week-un-says-1.6724335 https://www.unocha.org/yemen

UPDATE  I thank @nonplus for pointing out to me that, according to the EWP, the Saudi-led coalition would not count as "an armed group from Yemen" as the question refers.  As a consequence, since I had assessed the Saudi-led coalition as the most likely to engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Yemen, I now lower even more the chances for this outcome to happen (from 10% to a 5% chance).

I would say easily. This is a one year time period (365 days). 1000/365= 2.739 per day. According to Al Jazeera there are at least 4 air raids per day. The point of the air raids is to kill multiple people. https://www.ispionline.it/it/pubblicazione/yemens-military-tribal-army-warlords-19919: https://www.ecfr.eu/mena/yemen ;https://www.brookings.edu/blog/markaz/2017/12/18/who-are-the-houthis-and-why-are-we-at-war-with-them/ ;https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29319423; https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/yemen ; https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-47711413 ; http://www.geonames.org/YE/largest-cities-in-yemen.html ; https://interactive.aljazeera.com/aje/2018/Saudi-Arabia-air-raids-on-Yemen/index.html ; https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/yemen-war-death-toll-saudi-arabia-allies-how-many-killed-responsibility-a8603326.html

The UK independent reported according to the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project that between March 2015 and October 2018 up to 80,000 people may have been killed (https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/yemen-war-death-toll-saudi-arabia-allies-how-many-killed-responsibility-a8603326.html). The same source notes that the average is over 2,000 deaths per month since December 2017, although not always by a single armed group. As the Coalition surrounds Al-Hudaydah and thousands of people are under the threat of starvation and disease. In March, the Independent noted Oxfam's report that one person was being killed roughly every eight hours in the port still despite the ceasefire (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/yemen-war-ceasefire-stockholm-agreement-death-toll-a8828866.html). Ultimately, a systematic campaign anywhere in the country that causes 1,000 fatalities is unlikely, but as the EU documents almost 130,000 cases of Cholera in Hudaydah (https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/171123_DailyMap_Yemen_Cholera_versionRED.pdf)  and as the port is still in a form of blockade, a sudden outbreak of disease related fatalities remains a possibility, with the responsibility lying mostly with Coalition forces refusing to allow in most humanitarian aid.

The Yemeni civil war has led to the deaths of over 10,000+ civilians and the complications from the faltering infrastructure of the country has led to more disasters such as famines and disease outbreaks.  The civil war's stalemate increases the likelihood of some group to perpetrate mass killings as well as the insecurity of resources. Saudi led military movements and actions has led to the deaths of many civilians, where some call this a genocide due to their targeting of civilians with white phosphorous weapons. The lack of infrastructure, stalemate, and Saudi actions  has a likely chance of a systematic campaign of violence against civilians to occur.

Geeze, dark question, even by my standards. And the username I chose means slaughterhouse.  The Houthis are reckless, and probably a touch stupid, but they aren't intentional genocide reckless. Accidental genocide, maybe, but not intentional genocide.  The Saudis are also disinclined from mass murder, partially because of the Khashoggi incident of course. They don't much care for Yemeni lives, but even they will try to restrain their militias and fighters.
The possibility of this happening can not be ruled out. However, 1,000 or more people being killed is an unlikely high number for this possible scenario, even given a one year time frame.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 16.1%. [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 45%.
- "On 8 January 2019, the Council on Foreign Relations listed this conflict as a conflict to watch during 2019. Similarly, the Italian Institute for International Political Studies also claimed it to be a conflict to watch in 2019." [2] Inside view:
- From EWP: "The civilian population of Yemen has suffered tremendously during the country’s ongoing war, including from indiscriminate aerial bombardment and from a war-triggered humanitarian crisis. Yemen has been ranked sixth or higher in each of our past three annual assessments. Significant risk factors that contributed to the current assessment include a lack of freedom of movement for men, the country’s anocratic regime type, its geographic region, the presence of political killings, and ongoing armed conflict. It should be noted, as we explained in a November 2015 blog post, that our project’s definition of mass killing excludes situations in which one country’s armed forces attack civilians in another country’s territory. Thus, killings perpetrated by foreign militaries are reflected neither in this forecast nor in its underlying data." According to this definition, Saudi Arabia's campaign does not count. The Houthi seem to target mainly Saudi forces, not civilians from what I can tell. [2]
- ISIL was active in Yemen in the past, but doesn't seem to be anymore. [3]
- Al-Qaeda has been active in Yemen. [4] However, they seem to be involved in the fighting as opposed to deliberately targeting civilians. Overall judgment:
- to me the situation seems worse than it is in terms of mass killing campaigns under the definition of this question. Both EWP and crowd seem to be off here.
- I find it hard to give a concrete scenario that involves 1,000 deliberately killed civilians. These would have to be quite novel developments.
- therefore, my informed gut judgment is 5%.  [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/yemen
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yemeni_Civil_War_(2015%E2%80%93present)#2017
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant_%E2%80%93_Yemen_Province
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda_in_the_Arabian_Peninsula#Operations_and_activities_carried_out_as_al-Qaeda_in_Yemen_and_Saudi_Arabia

The Yemeni Civil War is an ongoing conflict that began in 2015 between two factions: the internationally recognized Yemeni government, led by Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, and the Houthi armed movement, along with their supporters and allies. Both claim to constitute the official government of Yemen. According to the UN and other sources, only from March 2015 to December 2017, between 8,670–13,600 people were killed in Yemen, including more than 5,200 civilians, as well as estimates of more than 50,000 dead as a result of an ongoing famine due to the war. The stalemate has produced an unrelenting humanitarian crisis, with at least 8.4 million people at risk of starvation and 22.2 million people - 75% of the population - in need of humanitarian assistance, according to the UN. Severe acute malnutrition is threatening the lives of almost 400,000 children under the age of five. The UN (2019) considers Yemen to be the world’s largest humanitarian crisis, with 14 million people at risk of starvation and recurrent outbursts of deadly diseases.  However, regardless of the above-mentioned terrific numbers and trends, it is important to look carefully to what the question is asking. The key-word here  is “systematically”,  which is then defined as “campaigns that systematically kill civilians include, but are not limited to, policies which intentionally kill civilians en masse (e.g., military strategies that intentionally target civilians, mass execution of a specific group) and policies that knowingly result in widespread death (e.g., mass starvation, confiscation of health care supplies, forced relocation)”. Therefore, regardless of the massive death toll in Yemen, it seems that both sides (Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi and the Houthi armed movement) lack the ability to effectively carry out an intentional mass killing as such.  That said, it would be naïve to treat Yemen was just as an internal conflict. The conflict has widely been seen as an extension of the Iran-Saudi Arabia proxy conflict and as a means to combat Iranian influence in the region. Not by chance, the conflict escalated dramatically in March 2015, when Saudi Arabia and eight other mostly Sunni Arab states - backed by the US, UK, and France - began air strikes against the Houthis, with the declared aim of restoring Mr Hadi's government. In this regard, according to the UN, more than 60% of civilian deaths have been the result of Saudi-led air strikes. Furthermore, Human Rights Watch (HRW) wrote that the Saudi-led air campaign that began on 26 March 2015, had "conducted airstrikes in apparent violation of the laws of war, such as the March 30 attack on a displaced persons camp in Mazraq, northern Yemen, that struck a medical facility and a market". Nevertheless, since the beginning of the hostilities, no systematic death campaign has led to 1,000 or more civilians in Yemen. To tell the truth, if we look at the pattern in the long run, Yemen has never had a mass killing according to EWP. Terrorist groups, although well established on the territory, do not have the means to carry out such a massive campaign. At least not one party alone (as the question specifies: “the question will only resolve as yes if 1,000 civilian fatalities occur in one or more campaigns”).  The possibility of drone’s attacks by the international community’s airstrike, mainly by the USA, is also very unlikely. The Bureau of Investigative Journalism documented 415 strikes in Pakistan and Yemen by 2015, and according to the organization's estimates, between 423 and 962 deaths are believed to have been civilians. Even though the number of civilians of this trend is high, we must consider that is the total number of American’s strikes of two countries together (where Pakistan is the most affected) and that the research started counting the number of deaths from 2001, by far before the beginning of Yemen’s war. That said, neither if those drone strikes occurred all together between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020 and only in Yemen it would be enough to have considered it a massive killing of 1000 individuals or more.  The only actor which might lead to such an outcome is the Saudi-led coalition which, as said before, through its airstrikes has caused 60% of civilian deaths so far. Nevertheless, the successful negotiations in Stockholm and the following ceasefire agreed between the 2 sides, although close to collapse more than once, has significantly lowered the number of airstrikes. Whether it will be renewed and respected until 31 March 2020 or not is hard to say. However, even if not, the systematic killing of 1000 people before that date remains unlikely. Concluding, I believe that the only chance of the outcome “Yes” of this question occurring is represented by famine resulting from a systematic restriction/boycott of humanitarian aids and essential goods. Indeed, famine is reported as the first reason for death in Yemen. The Saudi-led coalition’s in the recent past has already delayed and diverted many aids, closed critical ports, and stopped goods from entering Houthi-controlled seaports. Considering the already critical condition of Yemen’s population, an increase of this practice would definitely make possible the death of 1000 or more people due to starvation. However, since the great number of factors contributing to starvation in Yemen, it would be difficult for statistical think tanks to point the finger to just one precise responsible/coalition in case of mass starvation. For this reason, I limit the likelihood that an armed group from Yemen engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more to a 10% chance.  Sources:
-https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yemeni_Civil_War_(2015%E2%80%93present)#Drone_strikes
-https://nordic.businessinsider.com/yemen-conflict-explained-2019-2?r=US&IR=T
-https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29319423
-https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/dec/13/yemen-ceasefire-agreed-for-vital-port-city-of-hodeidah
-https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2018/11/15/experts-discuss-the-war-in-yemen-and-the-role-of-international-actors/
-https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/risk-mass-killing-rose-yemen-2016-report-170720045624573.html
-https://www.acleddata.com/?s=Yemen&id=m
-https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/yemen#8ee1c4

The question is really if the current ceasefire holds for the next year. Looking at the Syrian civil war ceasefires, the early ones held for a shorter time than the most recent. None have held for over a year. However, there are more competing rebel groups in Syria.

Because of my intuition (joke). I have met some of them and they would never get so far.

The key word here is "systematic." While the combat in Yemen has seen terrible losses on both sides of the conflict, both sides lack the ability to effectively carry out an intentional mass killing and the impetus. Looking at systematic killing campaigns in general, genocide tends to occur when one side or another has an outsize control over the battlespace and a relative monopoly on violence within the area. In Yemen, currently, neither side has complete control on the situation and the influence of out-of-state actors act as somewhat of a guard against one side gaining the definite upper hand. Further, while both sides are still vying for support from yet more out of state actors such as the U.S, neither side has a motivation to carry out as widely unpopular a campaign such as planned killings. https://kh.boell.org/en/2016/10/06/why-genocide-occurs
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2018/11/15/experts-discuss-the-war-in-yemen-and-the-role-of-international-actors/
